title: Authors and Citation
text: Léguillette C, Cren P, Drouet Y (2024). siminsee: Simulate survival trial data censoring. R package version 0.1.0.
code: @Manual{,   title = {siminsee: Simulate survival trial data with censoring},   author = {Clémence Léguillette and Pierre-Yves Cren and Youenn Drouet},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.0}, }

what: Simulate survival trial data with censoring
title: Simulate survival trial data with censoring
text: goal siminsee simulate survival trial data censoring various scenarios using hospital INSEE administrative data.

title: Simulate survival trial data with censoring
text: can install development version siminsee like :

title: Simulate survival trial data with censoring
text: use “nlisttrial” function simulate different scenarios parameters.
code: nlisttrial(scenario = 2,    nrepeat = c(1, 3),   nbp = c(5, 4),   lambda0 = rep(0.00175601, 2),   HR = c(1, 0.7),   tacc =  rep(60, 2),   tfu =  rep(60, 2),   lambda_pdv1 = rep(0.01, 2),   lambda_pdv2 = rep(0.01, 2),   t_pdv2 = rep(36, 2),   HR_pdv = rep(1, 2),   pinsee0 = rep(0.9, 2),   pinsee1 = rep(0.9, 2),   seed = 2023) #> $dat #> # A tibble: 17 × 25 #>    scenario nrepeat    id gr    time_accrual fu_theo delevt_true evt_true #>       <int>   <int> <int> <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl>       <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1        1       1     1 0               12     108       108          0 #>  2        1       1     2 1               24      96        56.3        1 #>  3        1       1     3 0               36      84        84          0 #>  4        1       1     4 1               48      72        72          0 #>  5        1       1     5 0               60      60        60          0 #>  6        2       1     1 0               15     105       105          0 #>  7        2       1     2 1               30      90        90          0 #>  8        2       1     3 0               45      75        75          0 #>  9        2       1     4 1               60      60        60          0 #> 10        2       2     1 0               15     105       105          0 #> 11        2       2     2 1               30      90        90          0 #> 12        2       2     3 0               45      75        75          0 #> 13        2       2     4 1               60      60        60          0 #> 14        2       3     1 0               15     105       105          0 #> 15        2       3     2 1               30      90        90          0 #> 16        2       3     3 0               45      75        75          0 #> 17        2       3     4 1               60      60        60          0 #> # ℹ 17 more variables: pdv_true1 <dbl>, del_cens <dbl>, delevt_hop <dbl>, #> #   evt_hop <dbl>, pdv_hop <dbl>, exv_hop <dbl>, info_insee <int>, #> #   evt_insee <dbl>, evt_hopinsee <dbl>, delevt_hopinsee <dbl>, #> #   pdv_hopinsee <dbl>, exv_hopinsee <dbl>, delevt_hopinseeimp <dbl>, #> #   evt_hopinseeimp <dbl>, pdv_hopinseeimp <dbl>, exv_hopinseeimp <dbl>, #> #   imm_hopinseeimp <dbl> #>  #> $parameters #> # A tibble: 2 × 13 #>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2 #>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1        1       1     5    60    60 0.00176   1          0.01        0.01 #> 2        2       3     4    60    60 0.00176   0.7        0.01        0.01 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl>

title: Simulate survival trial data with censoring
text: use ‘resu_dat_1gr’ function calculate percentages patients events, lost follow-, excluded alive immortal according estimation approach repetition scenario simulated data. use ‘ana_1gr’ function perform Cox model analyses simulated data compare estimation approaches (hospital data, hospital data + INSEE hospital data + INSEE + imputation). function returns Hazard Ratios comparing estimation approaches estimation based true data scenario repetition. function used patients group (‘HR’ function trial equal 1).
code: sim <- nlisttrial(scenario = 6,    nrepeat = rep(1, 6),   nbp = rep(5000, 6),   lambda0 = c(rep(0.00175601, 3), rep(0.0085, 3)),   HR = rep(1, 6),   tacc = rep(60, 6),   tfu = rep(60, 6),   lambda_pdv1 = rep(0.01, 6),   lambda_pdv2 = rep(0.01, 6),   t_pdv2 = rep(36, 6),   HR_pdv = rep(1, 6),   pinsee0 = rep(c(0.8, 0.9, 0.99), 2),   pinsee1 =rep(c(0.8, 0.9, 0.99), 2),   seed = 2023)  resu_dat_1gr(sim) #> $result #> # A tibble: 6 × 13 #>   scenario nrepeat p_evt_true p_evt_hop p_pdv_hop p_exv_hop p_evt_hopinsee #>      <int>   <int>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>          <dbl> #> 1        1       1      0.14     0.0944     0.557     0.349          0.130 #> 2        2       1      0.14     0.0944     0.557     0.349          0.134 #> 3        3       1      0.14     0.0944     0.557     0.349          0.139 #> 4        4       1      0.511    0.349      0.447     0.204          0.480 #> 5        5       1      0.511    0.349      0.447     0.204          0.495 #> 6        6       1      0.511    0.349      0.447     0.204          0.509 #> # ℹ 6 more variables: p_pdv_hopinsee <dbl>, p_exv_hopinsee <dbl>, #> #   p_evt_hopinseeimp <dbl>, p_pdv_hopinseeimp <dbl>, p_exv_hopinseeimp <dbl>, #> #   p_imm_hopinseeimp <dbl> #>  #> $parameters #> # A tibble: 6 × 13 #>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2 #>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1        1       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01 #> 2        2       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01 #> 3        3       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01 #> 4        4       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01 #> 5        5       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01 #> 6        6       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl> ana_mult_1gr(sim) #> $result #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   scenario nrepeat HR_hop HR_hopinsee HR_hopinseeimp #>      <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl> #> 1        1       1  1.02         1.42          0.924 #> 2        2       1  1.02         1.47          0.954 #> 3        3       1  1.02         1.53          0.994 #> 4        4       1  0.994        1.28          0.923 #> 5        5       1  0.994        1.31          0.960 #> 6        6       1  0.994        1.34          0.996 #>  #> $parameters #> # A tibble: 6 × 13 #>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2 #>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1        1       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01 #> 2        2       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01 #> 3        3       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01 #> 4        4       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01 #> 5        5       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01 #> 6        6       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl> sim <- nlisttrial(scenario = 9,                    nrepeat = rep(1, 9),                   nbp = rep(500, 9),                   lambda0 = c(rep(0.001756009, 3), rep(0.008513760, 3), rep(0.02310490, 3)),                   HR = rep(1, 9),                   tacc = rep(60, 9),                   tfu = rep(60, 9),                   lambda_pdv1 = rep(c(0.01, 0.01, 0.02), 3),                   lambda_pdv2 = rep(c(0.01, 0.02, 0.02), 3),                   t_pdv2 = rep(36, 9),                   HR_pdv = rep(1, 9),                   pinsee0 = rep(0.9, 9),                   pinsee1 =rep(0.9, 9),                   seed = 2023) graph_surv1gr(sim) res <- ana_mult_1gr(sim) graph_HR1gr_tt2(res)

title: Simulate survival trial data with censoring
text: use ‘ana_mult_2gr’ function perform Cox model analyses simulated data compare 2 groups (example treatment). function returns results analyses 4 estimation approaches (true data, hospital data, hospital data + INSEE hospital data + INSEE + imputation) scenario repetition. use ‘mean_coeff_ana_2gr’ function mean estimations coefficients Cox modeling repetitions scenario.
code: sim <- nlisttrial(scenario = 2,                   nrepeat = rep(5, 2),                    nbp = rep(2000, 2),                    lambda0 = c(0.00175601,  0.0085),                    HR = rep(0.7, 2),                    tacc =  rep(60, 2),                    tfu =   rep(60, 2),                    lambda_pdv1 = c(0.01, 0.01),                    lambda_pdv2 = c(0.01,0.02),                    t_pdv2 = rep(36,2),                    HR_pdv = c(1,1.1),                    pinsee0 = rep(0.9, 2),                    pinsee1 = rep(0.9, 2),                   seed = 2023) ana_mult_2gr(sim) #> $result #> # A tibble: 10 × 30 #>    scenario nrepeat log_HR_true HR_true waldtest_true pval_test_true #>       <dbl>   <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl> #>  1        1       1      -0.285   0.752          4.73       2.96e- 2 #>  2        1       2      -0.311   0.733          5.77       1.63e- 2 #>  3        1       3      -0.428   0.651         11.7        6.34e- 4 #>  4        1       4      -0.231   0.794          3.40       6.51e- 2 #>  5        1       5      -0.398   0.672          8.48       3.60e- 3 #>  6        2       1      -0.323   0.724         22.8        1.83e- 6 #>  7        2       2      -0.280   0.756         17.6        2.68e- 5 #>  8        2       3      -0.385   0.680         35.2        2.90e- 9 #>  9        2       4      -0.334   0.716         26.5        2.63e- 7 #> 10        2       5      -0.453   0.636         46.3        1.03e-11 #> # ℹ 24 more variables: success_uni_cox_true <dbl>, failure_cox_true <dbl>, #> #   success_bi_cox_true_true <dbl>, log_HR_hop <dbl>, HR_hop <dbl>, #> #   waldtest_hop <dbl>, pval_test_hop <dbl>, success_uni_cox_hop <dbl>, #> #   failure_cox_hop <dbl>, success_bi_cox_true_hop <dbl>, #> #   log_HR_hopinsee <dbl>, HR_hopinsee <dbl>, waldtest_hopinsee <dbl>, #> #   pval_test_hopinsee <dbl>, success_uni_cox_hopinsee <dbl>, #> #   failure_cox_hopinsee <dbl>, success_bi_cox_true_hopinsee <dbl>, … #>  #> $parameters #> # A tibble: 2 × 13 #>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2 #>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1        1       5  2000    60    60 0.00176   0.7        0.01        0.01 #> 2        2       5  2000    60    60 0.0085    0.7        0.01        0.02 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl> res <- ana_mult_2gr(sim)  mean_coeff_ana_2gr(res) #> $result #> # A tibble: 2 × 28 #>   scenario nrepeat exp_m_log_HR_true m_log_HR_true p_suc_uni_true p_suc_bi_true #>      <dbl>   <dbl>             <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl>         <dbl> #> 1        1       5             0.718        -0.331            0.8             0 #> 2        2       5             0.701        -0.355            1               0 #> # ℹ 22 more variables: p_fail_true <dbl>, exp_m_log_HR_hop <dbl>, #> #   m_log_HR_hop <dbl>, biais_abs_hop <dbl>, biais_rel_hop <dbl>, #> #   p_suc_uni_hop <dbl>, p_suc_bi_hop <dbl>, p_fail_hop <dbl>, #> #   exp_m_log_HR_hopinsee <dbl>, m_log_HR_hopinsee <dbl>, #> #   biais_abs_hopinsee <dbl>, biais_rel_hopinsee <dbl>, #> #   p_suc_uni_hopinsee <dbl>, p_suc_bi_hopinsee <dbl>, p_fail_hopinsee <dbl>, #> #   exp_m_log_HR_hopinseeimp <dbl>, m_log_HR_hopinseeimp <dbl>, … #>  #> $parameters #> # A tibble: 2 × 13 #>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2 #>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1        1       5  2000    60    60 0.00176   0.7        0.01        0.01 #> 2        2       5  2000    60    60 0.0085    0.7        0.01        0.02 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl> mean_res <- mean_coeff_ana_2gr(res)  graph_biais_grp_tt2(mean_res) graph_beta_grp_tt2(mean_res) graph_alpha_grp_tt2(mean_res)

what: We analyze with a Cox model the data contained in 'dat' to compare the 3 different estimation approaches with the estimation based on true data for each scenario and each repetition This function should be used when all patients are in the same group ('HR' in function trial should be equal to 1) — ana_mult_1gr
title: We analyze with a Cox model the data contained in 'dat' to compare the 3 different estimation approaches with the estimation based on true data for each scenario and each repetition This function should be used when all patients are in the same group ('HR' in function trial should be equal to 1) — ana_mult_1gr
text: analyze Cox model data contained 'dat' compare 3 different estimation approaches estimation based true data scenario repetition function used patients group ('HR' function trial equal 1)

title: We analyze with a Cox model the data contained in 'dat' to compare the 3 different estimation approaches with the estimation based on true data for each scenario and each repetition This function should be used when all patients are in the same group ('HR' in function trial should be equal to 1) — ana_mult_1gr

We analyze with a Cox model the data contained in 'dat' to compare the 3 different estimation approaches with the estimation based on true data for each scenario and each repetition This function should be used when all patients are in the same group ('HR' in function trial should be equal to 1) — ana_mult_1gr

title: We calculate mean coefficients over repetitions for each scenario — mean_coeff_ana_2gr
text: function returns list containing dataset mean coefficients scenario: Exponential mean log Hazard Ratios Mean log Hazard Ratios Mean absolute biais Mean relative biais Percentage success unilateral (estimation risk alpha HR = 1, estimation power HR < 1) Percentage success bilateral (estimation risk alpha HR = 1) Percentage failures (estimation power HR > 1) dataset containing simulations parameters

what: We simulate different trials with possibly different parameters specified in arguments for each scenario — nlisttrial
title: We simulate different trials with possibly different parameters specified in arguments for each scenario — nlisttrial
text: simulate different trials possibly different parameters specified arguments scenario

title: We simulate different trials with possibly different parameters specified in arguments for each scenario — nlisttrial
code: nlisttrial(   scenario = 1,   nrepeat = 1,   nbp = 1000,   tacc = 60,   tfu = 60,   lambda0 = 0.03,   HR = 1,   lambda_pdv1 = 0.01,   lambda_pdv2 = 0.02,   t_pdv2 = 36,   HR_pdv = 1,   pinsee0 = 0.95,   pinsee1 = 0.95,   seed = 2023 )

title: We simulate different trials with possibly different parameters specified in arguments for each scenario — nlisttrial
text: scenario : number scenarios (default 1 scenario) nrepeat : vector containing number repetitions scenario (default 1 repetition) nbp : vector containing number patients scenario (defaut 1,000 patients) tacc : vector containing accrual duration months scenario (default 60 months) tfu : vector containing follow-duration months scenario (default 60 months) lambda0 : vector containing rate exponential distribution scenario (default 0.03) HR : vector containing Hazard Ratio survival group 0 group 1 scenario (default 1) lambda_pdv1 : vector containing rate lost follow-patients time 't_pdv2' scenario (default 0.01) lambda_pdv2 : vector containing rate lost follow-patients time 't_pdv2' scenario (default 0.02) t_pdv2 : vector containing time rate lost follow-changes scenario (default 36) HR_pdv : vector containing Hazard ratio lost follow-group 0 group 1 scenario (default 1) pinsee0 : vector containing administrative file completeness (insee) group 0 scenario (default 0.95) pinsee1 : vector containing administrative file completeness (insee) group 1 scenario (default 0.95) seed : seed used generate scenario

title: We simulate different trials with possibly different parameters specified in arguments for each scenario — nlisttrial
text: function returns simulation dataset scenarios
